field.name: summary
field.value: Allow the configuration to "extends" another configuration

field.name: description
field.value:
For example, the following might the master config file:
<castle> <facilities> <facility id="nhibernatefacility"> <factory id="sessionFactory1"> <settings> ... <item key="hibernate.connection.connection_string">my connection string</item> </settings> </factory> </facility> </facilities> </castle>
And the following is a file that "extends" it:
<castle extends="../masterconfig.xml"> <components> <compoent id="x"/> </components> </castle>
The kernel should be unaware of this. It will only "see" the result:
<castle extends="../masterconfig.xml"> <facilities> <facility id="nhibernatefacility"> <factory id="sessionFactory1"> <settings> ... <item key="hibernate.connection.connection_string">my connection string</item> </settings> </factory> </facility> </facilities> <components> <compoent id="x"/> </components> </castle>
This feature should be clever enough to allow overrides. Suppose you have:
<castle extends="../masterconfig.xml"> <facilities> <facility id="nhibernatefacility"> <factory id="sessionFactory1"> <settings> <item key="hibernate.connection.connection_string">my other config</item> </settings> </factory> </facility> </facilities> </castle>
The kernel will see the overriden hibernate.connection.connection_string
This will, at least, simplify our test cases.
